reasoning: The critique targets an implied premise that achieving (near-)best futures depends mainly on collective moral choice and feasible coordination, and argues instead that competitive capability races select for speed rather than moral correctness. However, this essay is explicitly scoped to “point (1)” (target size / eutopian fragility) and explicitly defers the “navigation/coordination” questions to a later essay, so the attacked premise is not very central to the position as stated. Even if the critique were fully right about competitive selection effects, it would not substantially undermine the essay’s core claim that the ‘eutopian target’ is narrow/fussy across many moral views; at most it offers an alternative (or additional) explanation for why we won’t hit it by default. The critique is mostly clear and focused, with little fluff. Substantively, parts are plausible (multiple actors, race dynamics matter), but it overstates (“completely ignores,” “systematically outcompeted,” “premise … assumes coordination capacity that doesn’t exist”) given the essay’s explicit scoping and its acknowledgment that deliberate optimization/steering is a separate question.
title: Competitive dynamics select for speed over moral correctness in shaping futures
